div1.p: Reed describes his life in the military and a social outing.

div1.head: Letter from Lawrence Reed to Walter Reed, Emilie Lawrence Reed, and Blossom Reed, December 9, 1898
div1.p:
I got both of your letters in the same mail
and was very glad to hear from home, they came
the same day that the dear Paymaster did and
it is a very close shave which was the most
acceptable, Father spoke of the disagreeable part
of camp life, well I should say that we are getting
a little touch of the rough side of it, on account
of the cold, as the thermometer stands about 50° in
the day and goes down as low as 10° at night
as for myself I am very comfortably fixed, I
will give you a little descreption of the inside
of my tent. On the right hand side I have
a bed, made by my own hands filled with
straw which I sleep on with 3 blankets.
1 shelter tent, 1 poncho, 1 pr. pants. 1 coat, and
one over coat over me at nights and at that
the water freezes in the buckets in the center
at the back end in my box with all my clothes
and on the left hand side is all the battery
ammunition, which takes up the entire side
on the top of these is my toilet outfit & my mess
stuff. I brought my lamp with me and it comes
in beautifully, and the little oil stove which I
got in Savanah is the one thing I admire.
I tell you I burn oil in high style, 1 gallon per
each 36 hours. at the rate of 15¢ per gallon
and I suppose you know as well as I do what
an addition it is to ones tent. It has been raining
ever since yesterday noon, and it is now 7 P.M.
Sunday I took dinner at Miss Sullivans and
enjoyed myself ever so much and I took
in the Ladies German Tuesday night in full
dress. There was no getting out of it as Mr & Mrs
Sullivan insisted until I could no longer
refuse. I have been to town 3 times since I
have been here and we have been here 2 weeks
tomorrow, I have a very mean cold but I
suppose I am like the rest of the mob.

I spend all my money on tobacco, oil, butter
& bread & it takes every cent to run the ranch
I have quite a nice little spread except at
breakfast and then I simply freeze to death-
We get up at 7 AM and drill all day so much so
that Ive only seen Bob McMillane a few times
since we have been here-

As I must clean up for inspection tomorrow
I will close, Dont worry about the Lieut to
be, as he is O.K. and happy

Jill Mable I would love to hear from her
with dearest love for you all and
with a bright view to my commission
